Trenton,

I think you'll find that if you populate the data yourself you wi=
ll
test more then just nightly.  This would drastically improve your turn
a=
round time.

I think this is something good.

As for using mocks,  I was of=
 the opinion that they double the work
too.  Then I realized, the mock engi=
ne does most of the work for you,
if you are using interfaces that is.  Bas=
ically you just insert the
response from the mock object and you can forget=
 how the mock would
implement anything.  Saves me a lot of time once my co-=
workers and I
agree upon the interfaces.  Which is where the work SHOULD be=
.

Yes, you are going to fake the rest of the application.  However, If
you=
 are intending to test a separate application from your code, maybe
you sho=
uld just test that application alone.  For me, I like to test
things as sim=
ply as possible.  You could also supply a mock of your
code to allow them t=
o test using your code.

I see your point of needing acceptance and/or inte=
gration tests.  They
should be there too.  But, maybe as a separate suite t=
hat executes
less often.  (Like if you make a release (used loosely of cour=
se).)

Just my 0.02$,

Big Mike
